title: Integrating Conceptual and Procedural Knowledge of Fraction Division with Social Problem-Solving Project Strategies

context.prior_knowledge: Mastery of fundamental mathematical concepts (fractional operations) and core social studies concepts (citizenship, social structures), with intermediate-level application skills (data analysis, project design)
context.additional_context: For elementary school teacher candidates and education job-seekers, implementing a blended learning environment combining theory and practice. Focuses on simultaneously developing civic awareness and mathematical thinking through social problem-solving projects.

learning_goals: Students explain conceptual principles of fraction division (e.g., reciprocal multiplication) through visual models and verbal explanations with ≥85% accuracy and apply them to analyze social phenomena (e.g., resource distribution).
Learners achieve procedural fluency by solving diverse fraction division problems with ≥90% accuracy and interpret results in social contexts (e.g., budget allocation).

Over 2–4 weeks, learners complete a social studies-based project (e.g., designing solutions for local community issues) and write a teaching method proposal meeting the following conditions: 1) Integration of ≥3 social concepts (e.g., civic engagement, social equity, community collaboration) and ≥2 procedural skills (e.g., surveys, data visualization, stakeholder mapping), 2) ≥80% achievement on a rubric evaluating practical applicability in three aspects (field suitability, ease of implementation, effectiveness).
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
